description: standing man wearing a hat with a wide brim, pushed back on his head, with long ties and robe-like garment; man holds a pen in his PR hand and an open book in his PL hand; standing lion next to and behind man; columns and a wall with architectural details behind man, with landscape and buildings visible beyond columns; sheet trimmed into round shape (tondo)
provenance: Collection Chavaillon (until 2003; sale, Christophe Sabourin, Paris, May 31, 2003, no. 47, as attributed to Nikolaus Hogenberg, to Martel; [Galerie Monique Martel, Brussels, from 2003; sold to Muller]; [Klaas Muller, Brussels, until 2011; sold to Warshaw]; [Monroe Warshaw, New York, 2011-13]
text:
This design is for a type of stained glass produced in the Low Countries during the early 16th century. The panes were often circular and small. Such a highly finished drawing might have been shown to a patron before work began on the glass itself. The artist was a productive Antwerp Mannerist painter whose works lack signatures or other documentation. Historians assigned the name Master of 1518 based on the date inscribed on one of his altarpieces.

Saint Jerome is shown here as a gaunt, elderly scholar in a monastic setting. Accompanying him is the (charmingly elongated) lion that became his protector after Jerome removed a thorn from the beast’s paw. That tender scene appears in miniature in the background.
title: Saint Jerome
